epistemic humility is knowing life can come you and slap your metaphorical crown off any time.

'life' is a bit too romantic and vague, so let me just contextialize it by framing it as

"16-year olds today who are way smarter than you are at 32 and will totally eat your lunch because they're seeing what you were taught to unsee, questioning what you were taught to never question"

finally, the most supple and plastic brain adapts best. intelligence is just your ability to adapt.

the best way to go through life is actually like a simpleton with great sight and sensitivity. when you live without ideas, nothing is going against you and your identity; everything is you simply discovering yourself and the world.

sometimes, you discover desirable stuff. but mostly, you discover undesirable stuff.

but the more you discover the more your self loses preferences, the less things become desirable or undesirable. they're now simply new developments that you need to take into account, that's all.

your identity and stories about yourself lose valence and are relegated to mere descriptive conveniences. you turn into a simpleton with great sight and sensitivity.

caution: everything above was said way too easily.

the real mark of having your stuff together will always be how little you have to negotiate with yourself. that's primary. 

because it's easy to indulge in machiavellian posturing of the robert greene variety externally. but that's just insecurity masquerading as strength.

strip away the whole negotiation theater, and those folks are left with nothing. their power is just a performance with no real substance behind it. people who've truly got it figured out don't need any of that kabuki. they're aligned within, so the outside stuff just falls into place.
the biggest power move is not needing to negotiate at all.

the ability to negotiate is a crutch you develop at best when you don't have better leverage elsewhere.

in fact, the more you find yourself having to negotiate in your day-to-day life ‚Äî whether with yourself or others ‚Äî the worse you're doing.

it's a skill you over-index on when you don't have other skills.

i've rarely seen negotiation tactics as a mark of social acumen. salesmanship only reveals a lack of real clarity/know-how/power. and i judge how sorted someone is based on how much they have to negotiate with everything and everyone around them. the lesser, the better.

the people i have come to respect are the ones who glide through interactions without all the back-and-forth. to me, that's a sign they've got their sh*t together.

if the use case/central insight is delta-4, the ui can take a backseat. if it isn't, you better have great polish.

the problem in the "ship fast vs. ship something good" debate is that there's really no debate if you understand what features of the system are pulling the most weight and prioritize them over others.

if the core functionality solves a real pain, you can ship something hacky and it'll still be received well. and you can take as much time as you need in making it work. everything else is secondary and you can ship without those bells and whistles.

but if your core functionality is only a good-to-have, it better have other bragworthy propositions outside of the core functionality ‚Äî like excellent ux.

the more fundamental issue here is accurate prioritisation of what's pulling the most weight in any system. it's never about shipping fast or slow.

mark my words:

unless you genuinely appreciate greatness and desire it in yourself, you will never ever be great. 

you do not become great by hating greatness or rationalizing against it, you become great by

1. noticing your envy for brilliant traits
2. there's no step 2

if you keep noticing your envy for specific traits and keep noticing how those traits play out in general, you will naturally develop them in yourself. 

you will go through what i call "the effortless effort."

why does this happen?

because envy is a visceral signal for a desire that's genuine and authentic.

and genuine desires will always find a way to fulfillment. and the way they do this is by turning you into a student. 

many good traits in life i developed, i developed because i saw someone else have it and envied them deeply for it.

i see people masking their envy with a deep-rooted cynicism. it takes them nowhere. and most of them cope this way because they've been told envy is a terrible thing and they should be ashamed to feel it.

not at all.

envy is authenticity revealed in the process of interfacing with the world.

and it's hard to envy someone for something you do not genuinely desire. 

if this very desire is absent, no progress is possible.

often, you may think you envy someone for something salient, but upon further contemplation and enquiry, you find that you do not envy them for that thing at all, but something much deeper and mysterious. you realise you envy them not for the effect but the cause that produces the effect.

this is the whole process of noticing your envy. and the most truthful thing a student can say is, 

"i want what you have."

let me share a personal story to provide some context around why i'm such a sucker for professional honesty.

after working in hardware and web development for a year each, i transitioned to a full-time copywriting position in 2018 at a boutique design studio in mumbai with a 9-person team. i was their only copywriter.

while applying, i was impressed by their website and doubted i would hear back from them. had it been any other design agency, i probably wouldn't have. i had no portfolio or experience, just two links: a website i had written copy for during my stint as a django developer and my medium profile with a few blog posts.

i wouldn't have gotten my first big break in a full-time creative writing role if it weren't for ankur rander, the creative director, who spotted my latent talent and trusted me with the position.

besides his clarity of thought, design philosophy, and the attention to detail and craftsmanship he instilled in me during my year at the studio, two incidents are engraved in my memory.

the first was when i sent him the communication strategy for a client's website. 

as he browsed the deck, he loved the central idea/positioning and reviewed the content samples i had crafted. he pointed out which lines worked and which didn't, noting that many were incompatible with the positioning and created confusion rather than clarity.

after going through the deck, he turned to me and said something i'll never forget: 

"mustafa, if you have two good lines, only give me those two. never give me 10 for the sake of filling the deck."

i learned two things from him that day:

1. never compromise clarity for the sake of optics.
2. always help the reader build clarity and manage their experience at every step

the second incident ‚Äî the more relevant one ‚Äî occurred when we were working with a pesky client known for bad taste and accepting only mediocre ideas. 

the entire creative team (excluding rander) agreed to give the client what they wanted on the first attempt to save time under a tight deadline.

i remember presenting it to rander over speaker phone, with the team huddled around. and he thrashed me in front of everyone.

"mustafa, this is really bad work. you have put absolutely no thought into this. please redo it; this is unacceptable."

getting defensive, i explained our reasoning around the client's lack of appetite and why they wouldn't accept something really creative anyway.

"it doesn't matter what the client will accept. it is our responsibility to suggest what we think is best. if they still don't accept it, we can revise."

i learned a crucial lesson that day: never compromise my own work for the sake of someone else's lack of imagination.

i've only become more opinionated and brutal since then, and people who've worked closely with me after that have only loved me for it ‚Äî although it has been hard for them.

this isn't toxicity. it's kindness. it's real mentorship. and i wouldn't be where i am today without rander's stick.

to upskill in any real way, the stakes need to be high. if you can't raise them for yourself, you need an absolutely honest person with high standards to push you to raise them. you need to have a clear mirror. or you will never improve.

no one understands this better than masters, who demonstrate an absolute mastery in tackling questions in a way that land with the person they're talking to. 

i have found them to have the requisite sensitivity to see where a student is coming from and what baggage/conditioning she has come with to the master's door.

and then there's an even more fundamental realisation behind this, which is,

most questions are posed in bad faith; the student is asking them to validate the answer he already has. handling such a person with grace is even trickier ‚Äî for you see how motivated their reasoning already is, and how blocked they are to actually being a student, for once. but you also need to bring them closer to understanding at the same time.

truth isn't wise or unwise, but speaking it into existence does demand a lot of wisdom.

you need to both read a lot and do a lot to triangulate any core concept for yourself.

can't rely on any one single explanation/definition. the more fundamental a property is in the world, the more entry points you will have into explaining it. only some will do the trick. and they will vary from audience to audience.

this is the core difference between a good teacher and a bad one. a good teacher knows what entry point into an explanation will activate the right mental motions in the student and allow them to really grasp the concept.

here's a general rule of thumb i've identified for explaining things well: 

never use terms and analogies in an explanation that associate with several irrelevant ideas. they will only take the student away from the explanation instead of leading them into it. they will make your job harder.

for example, if you wish to explain non-duality/truth/spirituality, refrain from mentioning buddhism/hinduism/any other religion in your explanations. they're loaded notions that immediately flood the mind with irrelevant associations. they carry the reader/student away from your explanation.

if i wished to explain wealth creation, i would refrain citing examples featuring adani, ambani, mallya, etc. won't be helpful.

remember that no student is a blank slate. your ideas will be received by a room full of unhelpful or downright hostile associations. and you have to either work with those, or better, completely avoid those in order to make your points land without them being escorted and shot by existing ideas/memes/ideologies.

see the thing is, i do not disagree with anything you're saying. and your knowledge of how finance works is likely to be a lot better than mind. but i do not think "banks make loans" is a good entry into the explanation. that's all.

also, i wouldn't say "linux is not valued much in money terms"

there's a huge difference between 'being valued' and 'being asked to pay money for it'

good read. you might want to pay attention to three things ‚Äî

1. managing scope creep
2. getting to the point faster within each metaphor
3. not structuring the argument using mece.

elaboration ‚Äî

1. i know it's exciting to cram everything in. curious people tend to have many tangents they wish to explore sll at once. but it's not a great experience for the reader.

this piece would benefit from a healthy amount of editing and removing a lot of stuff out. would probably break it down into two/three separate essays with clearer spines.

2. the pacing is off as you tend to ramble with obscure detail in many places. readers will zone out if they can't immediately connect the biological detail to the point you're trying to make. need to get to the point faster in every paragraph/subsection

as an editor, i would focus on biology only to the extent that lends to the metaphor. because the point isn't to educate people on human biology. the point is to flesh out the metaphor at the right level of abstraction.

3. mece makes essays boring to read because every section feels disconnected from the rest. the central argument doesn't naturally blend from one paragraph/section to the next. the result is the reader feels you're jumping around. btw, you're hopping categories too ‚Äî talking about protein and carbs and also talking about organs. it feels messy.

not saying every essay needs to avoid mece. but most could benefit from not falling in the simplistic and crude mece trap. it takes out all the style and flavour from the writing.

conclusion:
the language is simple and clear. the metaphor is interesting and makes sense. but it feels like a first draft. wouldn't be surprised if it is.

businesses and being principled do not really go together. an individual can be ethical and place his principles above money, because money is not primary to his existence. but a business, by definition, has to place money above everything else if it has to continue being in business. 

and when you put money at the center of everything, you can't help but get tangled up with the market and all its preferences. because money does not exist in isolation. and if profit is your raison d'√™tre, you can't help but be enslaved by everything that contributes to making that profit.

as a business scales, aligning its p&l with its personal values and moral judgments becomes increasingly harder. and the demands of the business make personal ethics irrelevant. the bottom line is a hard taskmaster.

it's a lucky business that can survive for decades without ever coming into some huge conflict with the market. it is usually only true for small businesses that never expand and exist in a monoculture. they are the exception rather than the rule.

finally, a business will always assume the shape of the market's most inflexible preferences. or it stops being in business. 

if you're also running a business at scale, judging another for not having any principles would be hypocritical. you have compromised them too. you only do not talk about it.

for the longest time, i have advocated craft and against politicking and optics, some through my own twitter, and some via other faces.

i'm a nut myself. right since the very beginning, i have despised playing the career game. i entered my professional life with a naive, idealistic mindset. almost a childish romanticism that path 2 people would laugh at.

but i have been lucky enough and successful enough in my own estimation following path 1. because path 2 was never an option in my books.

(dude, i SUCK at interviews. if someone asks me a question that expects an answer that could potentially throw me in a really positive light, i would fuck it up. and i suck because i do not care about it. i think it's stupid.)

but having seen more of the professional world, i know that craft philosophy and advice doesn't fly for most people and path 2 is the pragmatic and safe option for most.

i can never get myself to actively support it though. it's too calculative and machiavellian for my naive ass.

there are two approaches to a successful career:

1. be invested in the game
2. game the game

this is the classic craft mindset vs. politick/dhandha mindset debate that's going on for a while now.

path 1:

difficult, because it requires a lot of luck, self-awareness, and obsession to arrive at craft and do good there.

it also frontloads all the risk involved in experimentation in your early years, which is why having a basic safety net is indispensable. it also requires a lot of brutal honesty that few are ready for.

but once you get there, life is easier without a lot of hustle. your work satisfies you financially, morally, and spiritually. and you develop an unshakeable confidence in your abilities.

it's clearly not for everyone, although it's what the world needs more of.

path 2:

also difficult and requires a lot of hustle and work to understand how the system itself functions.

but it's the pragmatic path for everyone who isn't doing well in the luck and obsession department.

it will lead to better monetary outcomes in the short term, for sure. it's very low risk.

but in the long run, you'll never be able to mitigate career risk or develop the kind of confidence being a craftsperson can.

and it won't produce any deep satisfaction or joy that craft offers, either. all your life will be spent in seeking work-life balance and playing your cards right.

but till the world is predictable enough, you will make good money without undertaking much risk.

conclusion:

i will not even tell you to choose your poison. because if you're choosing, you're by default in the second bucket. don't listen to steve jobs type people.

but if you're a steve jobs type nut, good luck. you have no choice in the matter.

@daglihet i do not think delusion is prescribable in any real sense, although i have written about it in ways that may have made it look that way in the past.

nor can i draw a logical connection between delusion and memories turning blue/memory loss.

for a few years now, or at least since i've become aware of it, my entire past has been tinged with sadness. every memory and recollection, regardless of its inherent emotional content, arrives accompanied by a melancholic undertone. even the happiest and most joyful moments, when they come up, leave me feeling sad.

as the character in that pixar movie inside out would put it, 

"all my memories have turned blue."

from experience, i know that today will feel blue tomorrow or whenever else i recall it next, but i can't logically explain why. 

i can think of many reasons, starting with my own perception of memory and how it can create suffering, but i still struggle to understand why i feel sad about something that has become merely blurry images in my mind.

it's not that i long to go back and relive those days. in fact, i find the notion of wanting to return to the past quite alien. if someone were to reminisce about the "good old days" and express a desire to relive them, i would frankly be at a loss. 

it's like trying to imagine a four-dimensional tesseract ‚Äì i simply can't do it.

perhaps this pervasive sadness is due to its indelibility in my memory as time passes, overshadowing other aspects of my recollection. it's possible that when i recall past events, the underlying sadness is retrieved with much greater clarity than any other detail.

this phenomenon may or may not be related to my deteriorating memory over the past few years. my memory has become so poor that i can rewatch entire movies without being able to recall what happens next. the only thing i can remember is the fact that i have seen the movie before; everything else is a complete blank.

nevertheless, all this is very interesting to me and raises some pertinent questions about how my life is going to look going forward.

if you think about it, the katti-batti protocol is quite similar in function to what the word "situationship" added to romantic relationships.

situationships have always been a thing. but before the word situationship entered the cultural lexicon, there was a gaping chasm between a platonic friendship and a serious relationship. finding themselves somewhere in the middle of the spectrum and unable to classify themselves into either bucket, couples faced a lot of anxiety that usually comes from being unable to classify one's position.

but once the word 'situationship' turned colloquial, couples no longer had to force each other towards either end of the spectrum. they were now on stable ground, with a lot of freedom and flexibility in terms of interpretation.

katti-batti offers a similar middle-ground for the spectrum of conflicts. it adds a quantization level, increases resolution, increases tolerances, and adds information to the system that wasn't available previously.

accelerationism is the nash equilibrium for the system. i would refrain from calling it optimal or suboptimal; it can be both, depending on how you see it.

if you do not accelerate, someone else will and you will have worse payoffs. so, the only equilibrium state is for everyone to accelerate.

those who choose to call it suboptimal are trying to force you out of the equilibrium state towards worse payoffs.

those who choose to call it optimal are practicing techno-optimism.

In reality, there is no relationship between two people at all. There is only a relationship between the image each one has of the other. 

Whenever I am talking to you, I am not talking to you, the person standing in front of me right now, I am talking to an image I have of you in my head based on my past interaction. And likewise, with you, you aren't talking to me as a living person standing in front of you right now, but you are talking to an image you have of me in your head. 

Now, what happens is the living entity is perpetually in flux, constantly changing and evolving. But since the living entity itself sees itself as an image and not as a living being, they do not realize the constant rift that's forming between the image that is in their head and the person they are constantly evolving into. 

So, this is essentially where stress arises from. It is a conflict between what your real whole self, living self wants to do in this present moment versus what you think you should do based on the image you have of yourself and what you think someone else should do based on the image you have of them. 

In reality, even they are changing constantly moment to moment like you are, but since the images are static, you don't really see or to put it even better, you prevent yourself from seeing the life change that is happening in front of your eyes because your eyes are clouded by the image and not the living entity. 

Now, small stresses and rifts between the image and the living entity during daily life can be overcome and are often reconciled by the person. But over a long enough time span, if the image remains sufficiently static and the living entity has wandered far away from that image, what happens is ultimately they will end up doing something that will be a huge shock to their personal image. 

These are moments where if the person in question is your own self, you end up finding out that you aren't the person you always thought you were. And if the person is your spouse or your friend, you similarly end up thinking that you've been betrayed by this person or you always thought they were a certain person but they really weren't. 

So this is the stress and suffering and anxiety that the identity, the image, brings into life. It obscures the life change happening within the person and many a times what can even happen is just to mitigate the stress, the person might suppress their genuine tendencies just to stay true to the image they and others already have about them. 

This, over a long period of time ‚Äî because the living entity has drifted far apart from the image of the entity ‚Äî can create psychological neuroses. And this is also why a lot of people require therapy because the image they portray to the world has not really changed in tandem with the living entity, the person behind the image. And over the years, they've suppressed a lot of natural tendencies that would have conflicted with this image.

This is why they say that the ego is the root of your suffering because the identity is just a complex combination of memes, ideas, images, behaviours, and preferences. But it's a very static thing. It usually does not change quite a lot except on a very superficial layer. For example, you might be hating coffee today and you might start drinking it tomorrow. That is sort of a change that is very easy to justify to others. Hence, such updations can be made easily. 

But a drastic change would be the kind where you've thought you're a good and righteous person all your life, but in a stressful situation, you commit such an evil act that not only are others shocked by your behaviour but you yourself are quite shocked by your own behaviour. Such changes in image are very hard to bring about because they go against everything you have believed about yourself. In truth, what you portray to the world doesn't really exist, it's an abstraction, while your living person is in constant flux with the environment and its genuine impulses and desires are too.

like every chain is only as strong as its weakest link, you're only as good as your baseline.

and what sets the baseline for how you write is how you think in your head. if you think in complete english sentences, and maintain a logical chain of reasoning, not skipping steps, and using precise words, you will think in the same words you write. and since you usually think 100x more than you write, you will be doing 100x as much writing as you were previously.

but if you treat writing as a separate performance, disconnected from your thinking, then you will always sound great in your head but end up confused in your writing. you find out you were fooling yourself all this while about your logical clarity and precision when there was none.

please understand this:

THERE IS NO LOGICAL CLARITY OR PRECISION WITHOUT SUPPLYING IT THE NECESSARY LANGUAGE THAT WOULD MAKE IT SO.

JUST LIKE THERE IS NO MATHEMATICAL PROOF WITHOUT DERIVING IT RIGOROUSLY ON PAPER.

it doesn't matter if you're thinking or writing. logic and clarity need the right tools and treatment to attain perfection.

you can't think clearly if you're not thinking in complete, logical sentences, with all the right words. 

but most people treat thinking as something expedient ‚Äî it's only in my mind, who cares, i can use any word i want, i have the liberty to not complete my sentences, etc.

so they never end up practicing as much. the practice starts in your head. and much of it is done in your head, even before the words make it to paper.

the point is not to break those strings. you don't need to. but you need to know those strings.

in fact, often, you will choose to obey the puppet master even after knowing how they're controlling you. you will choose to succumb to your fear. you will not find the courage to fight it.

but the very fact that you know the fear exists and that you succumbed to it is enough to make its grip loosen over you.

you only need to pay attention.

there's no need to be a sher or a bhaaloo or a wolf or an alpha. there's no need for such grandiose visions and performances. just see where you are and all the fears controlling you at all times. an incessant attention is enough.

believing that you have free will and acting in accordance with that belief is good, but it should be preceded by self-knowledge. without it, your free will is a prisoner's bravado inside the four walls of his prison.

you're making decisions and taking pride in exercising your free will. but those decisions aren't really yours and you didn't have any choice in the matter except to obey the puppet master.

it is impossible to freely choose without self-awareness.

in its absence the kind of choices you make are akin to being able to decide with which part of your body you wish to catch a bullet and die on the battlefield, when your real desire was to not enrol for the war.

it's not a choice at all. not in any way that matters.

unless you've come face to face with all the strings that are controlling you like a puppet, how can there be any free choice or will?

free choice only exists when you know everything that is influencing that choice.

without that knowledge, all your choices are merely an illusion of choice while you're being puppeteered by forces and reasons unknown to you.
